content:
ACOS v7 claimed 630+ skills and 158 agents.

I audited it. 630 were unvetted npm installs. 158 were empty session timestamps.

So I rebuilt the whole thing from zero.

v10 has 22 real skills, 8 real agents, and every number verified.

The actual hard problem in agentic AI: self-modification.

The smarter the system gets, the more it wants to edit its own config. Unchecked, it eventually makes itself dumber.

v10 solves this with a Self-Modify Gate. Snapshot config, apply change, re-score intelligence. Score drops more than 5 points? Auto-revert.

Experience Replay is the one I'm most excited about.

Every session generates a trajectory — tools used, order, outcome. Next time you start a similar task, the system finds the 2 most successful past runs and injects them as context.

60+ trajectories so far. 67% avg success. Getting better.

Agent IAM: same principle as enterprise security, applied to AI.

Music producer can't edit system configs. Content writer can't run bash. 6 profiles, each scoped to exactly the tools and directories they need.

Least-privilege for AI agents. Should've done this from day one.

Circuit Breaker stops the most common AI failure mode: trying the same broken approach 8 times.

3 failures on a file: warning.
5: restricted access.
8: full stop.

Resets on success or session end. Simple rule, saves hours.

Performance got better too. Hooks went from 15 to 7. Subprocess spawns per tool from 5-6 to 1-2. Removed everything that was informational-only.

Less noise. More signal. Turns out the best optimization is deleting things.

Open-source, free, MIT.

https://frankx.ai/blog/acos-v10-autonomous-intelligence
github.com/frankxai/agentic-creator-os

linkedin.content:
I audited my own AI operating system and found that most of it was a lie.

ACOS v7 claimed 630+ skills and 158 agents. Turns out 630 were unvetted npm installs. 158 were empty session timestamps. The intelligence score was 72 and trending sideways.

A little embarrassing. Also a good starting point.

v8 through v10 rebuilt everything on verified numbers. 22 real skills. 8 real agents. Intelligence score: 93.

The difference wasn't adding more features. It was adding 5 safety systems that let the system improve itself without breaking itself.

The one I'm most proud of: the Self-Modify Gate. It snapshots the config before any change, applies the change, re-scores intelligence, and auto-reverts if the score drops more than 5 points. The system can evolve. It can never make itself significantly dumber.

The one I use most: Experience Replay. 60+ session trajectories, each recording which tools worked in what order. New tasks get the 2 most similar past successes injected as context. It compounds.

Performance improved by deleting things. Hooks: 15 to 7. Subprocess spawns: 5-6 to 1-2. The best optimization turned out to be removing informational-only hooks nobody read.

Open-source, free.

https://frankx.ai/blog/acos-v10-autonomous-intelligence

#AIEngineering #OpenSource #DevTools

newsletter.preview: 630 skills were npm installs. 158 agents were timestamps. So I rebuilt it.
newsletter.body:
ACOS v7 claimed 630+ skills and 158 agents. I audited it. The 630 were unvetted npm installs. The 158 were empty session timestamps.

v10 has 22 real skills, 8 real agents, and an intelligence score of 93 (up from 72). The difference: 5 safety systems that let the system improve itself without breaking itself.

The Self-Modify Gate is the interesting one — snapshots config, applies changes, re-scores, auto-reverts if things get worse. The system can evolve. It can never degrade.

Open-source: https://frankx.ai/blog/acos-v10-autonomous-intelligence

content:
18 MCP servers loading every Claude Code session.
8 were broken.
4 were duplicates.

I didn't know any of this until I spent 30 minutes debugging it manually.

So I built a tool that does it in 10 seconds.

MCP servers accumulate like browser tabs. You install a few. Plugins add more. Claude.ai connectors add more. Before you know it, your config is 1,000 lines across 4 scopes and half of them fail silently.

There was zero tooling to diagnose this. Now there is.

mcp-doctor scans every scope, health-checks each server with real MCP handshakes, catches duplicates and missing env vars, and tells you what to keep, what to move to on-demand, and what to remove.

Copy-paste fix commands included.

My results: 18 servers down to 5 always-on. Zero broken. Zero duplicates. Startup noticeably faster.

Also ships with 10 preset packs — web-developer, ai-architect, content-creator, minimal — so you don't have to guess what a good setup looks like.

npx mcp-doctor audit

Free, MIT.

https://frankx.ai/blog/mcp-doctor-claude-code-server-optimization

linkedin.content:
18 MCP servers loading every Claude Code session. 8 were broken. I didn't know.

MCP servers are what make Claude Code actually powerful — browser automation, Slack, Vercel, image generation. But they accumulate silently. Plugins install them. Claude.ai connectors add more. Colleagues share configs with 5 servers you never use.

I spent 30 minutes manually debugging my setup and found three patterns that trip up every Claude Code user: scope confusion (same server in 4 places), silent failures (broken servers flash a warning and vanish), and no tiering (everything loads whether you need it or not).

So I built mcp-doctor. TypeScript CLI. Scans all scopes, health-checks with real MCP handshakes, catches duplicates, generates copy-paste fix commands.

My setup went from 18 broken servers to 5 clean ones in under a minute.

Ships with 10 preset packs (web-developer, ai-architect, content-creator, minimal) so you can start with something curated instead of accumulating random servers over time.

npx mcp-doctor audit

https://frankx.ai/blog/mcp-doctor-claude-code-server-optimization

#ClaudeCode #DeveloperTools #OpenSource

I had 18 MCP servers loading every Claude Code session. Eight were broken. Four were duplicates. Zero tooling existed to tell me.

mcp-doctor fixes this in 10 seconds. Scans all scopes, health-checks each server, detects duplicates and missing env vars, generates copy-paste commands.

Also ships with preset packs so you can start with a curated setup instead of guessing.

npx mcp-doctor audit

https://frankx.ai/blog/mcp-doctor-claude-code-server-optimization

content:
Simon Willison co-created Django and literally named prompt injection.

His AI engineering approach is the opposite of every hype thread. Constraints make systems better. That tracks with everything I've seen in production.

Treat the LLM as an observed system. Type hints. Schema definitions. Structured constraints.

The clearer your boundaries, the less the model hallucinates. This is engineering, not vibes.

The exploratory coding loop: never ask AI to build a whole app. Small testable chunks. Immediate execution. Feed results back into context.

High frequency, small surface area. That's how reliable code actually ships with LLMs.

Assume the model is untrusted. No direct shell access. No raw database queries. Hard boundaries between AI output and system execution.

The guy who named prompt injection runs his systems this way. Worth noting.

The pattern across all three: type hints over hope. Small loops over big prompts. Hard boundaries over trust.

Pragmatism scales. Magic doesn't.

https://frankx.ai/blog/ai-engineering-without-hype-willison

linkedin.content:
Simon Willison co-created Django and coined the term "prompt injection."

His approach to AI engineering is worth paying attention to because it's boring. In the best way.

Three principles that hold up in every production system I've worked on:

Treat the LLM as an observed system. Type hints and schema definitions reduce hallucination more than any clever prompt trick. The clearer your constraints, the more predictable the output.

Use the exploratory coding loop. Never ask AI to build a whole app. Small testable chunks, immediate execution, feed results back. High frequency iteration beats ambitious prompting every time.

Assume the model is untrusted. No direct shell access. No raw database queries. Hard boundaries between AI output and system execution. Same principle as enterprise security.

The pattern: constraints make AI better, not worse. This matches what we've learned building ACOS over 14 months — the system got significantly better when we added restrictions, not when we removed them.

https://frankx.ai/blog/ai-engineering-without-hype-willison

#AIEngineering #SoftwareArchitecture

newsletter.subject: The boring AI engineering that works
newsletter.preview: Simon Willison's approach. No hype. Just production patterns.
newsletter.body:
Simon Willison co-created Django and named prompt injection. His AI engineering approach is worth studying because it's the opposite of the hype cycle.

Three principles: treat the LLM as an observed system (type hints beat clever prompting), use the exploratory coding loop (small chunks, not big prompts), assume the model is untrusted (hard boundaries between output and execution).

The through-line: constraints make AI systems better. This matches what we learned building ACOS — the system improved when we added restrictions.

https://frankx.ai/blog/ai-engineering-without-hype-willison

content:
Claude Code manages my 12,000 AI songs, a production website, and enterprise consulting. Same tool, same context, same session memory.

The setup that makes this work took about 10 minutes.

One file — CLAUDE.md — in the project root. Contains projects, preferences, past decisions, patterns.

Claude reads it at every session start. Every session picks up where the last one left off. No re-explaining your codebase. That alone changes the experience.

MCP servers turn it from assistant into infrastructure. Vercel for deployments. Slack for notifications. Resend for email. File system for direct code edits.

It doesn't suggest things. It does things.

The part that compounds: trajectory learning. Every session records what tools worked in what order. After 30 days I had 60+ patterns the system could draw from.

67% success rate and improving. My AI assistant developed a memory. That was unexpected.

Whole system is open-source.

https://frankx.ai/blog/build-your-own-jarvis-claude-code
github.com/frankxai/agentic-creator-os

linkedin.content:
I use Claude Code to manage 12,000 AI songs, a production website at frankx.ai, and enterprise consulting projects. All from one tool.

The difference between "AI chatbot" and "personal infrastructure" is about 10 minutes of configuration.

One file — CLAUDE.md — in your project root. Projects, preferences, past decisions, coding patterns. Claude reads it at every session start. No more re-explaining your codebase. That single file changes the experience more than any prompt trick.

MCP servers extend it into actual infrastructure. Mine connect to Vercel (deployment), Slack (notifications), Resend (email), and the file system (direct code edits). The AI doesn't suggest changes. It makes them.

The part that surprised me: trajectory learning. Every session records which tools worked in what order. After 30 days I had 60+ patterns the system could reference. 67% success rate, improving.

I open-sourced the whole setup. 10 minutes to configure, and after a month you'll have an AI system that knows your codebase better than you remember it.

https://frankx.ai/blog/build-your-own-jarvis-claude-code

#ClaudeCode #DeveloperTools #OpenSource

content:
696,309 white-collar job cuts in the first 5 months of 2025. 80% jump year over year.

Most people read that and feel anxious.

I want to offer a different frame: the same tools cutting those jobs just made it absurdly cheap to build your own thing.

The math used to be: $50k+ upfront, team of 5, 18 months to first revenue.

Now it's $200/month in tools, a team of you plus AI agents, and real revenue in weeks.

The barrier to entry collapsed. The ceiling didn't.

Three things you have right now that didn't exist 3 years ago:

Claude Code and Cursor can build production software.
Content generation handles your marketing.
Midjourney and v0 give you enterprise-quality design.

One person's stack. Ten people's output.

The safest position isn't being good at a pattern-following job inside a company.

It's owning the business that deploys the AI.

This isn't about quitting tomorrow. It's about building something on the side while the salary's still coming in.

90-day action plan and the full data set.

https://frankx.ai/blog/the-great-transition-build-your-own-business

2020: $50k+ upfront. Team of 5. 18 months to first revenue.
2026: $200/month in tools. Team of one. Revenue in weeks.

29.8 million solopreneurs in the US already generate $1.7 trillion in annual revenue. 77% report being profitable in their first year. These aren't lottery numbers. This is a trend with structural momentum.

The jobs most at risk follow patterns — legal research, financial analysis, code review, marketing copy. The safest position isn't being excellent at one of these inside a company. It's owning the business that deploys the AI.

content:
12,000+ AI songs in. The single most important thing I've learned about Suno:

It doesn't follow instructions. It captures vibes.

"Make the drums louder" does nothing. "Powerful driving drums" changes everything.

The formula that consistently works:

Genre + Tempo + Instruments + Vocals + Mood + Special Elements

"Cinematic orchestral, 90 BPM, sweeping strings and brass, ethereal female vocals, triumphant and expansive, dramatic build"

That produces something. "Epic movie music" produces noise.

Genre stacking is the move nobody talks about.

Don't write "rock." Write "Alternative rock meets post-punk, angular guitars, tight rhythm section, deadpan vocals."

The intersection is where originality lives. Suno needs specificity to surprise you.

Vocal control after thousands of generations:

"Whispered verses, belted chorus" — instant dynamic range.
"Baritone" or "soprano" — sets register.
"Humming intro" — atmosphere before lyrics.
"No vocals, instrumental only" — when the music needs space.

Describe the feeling. Not the instruction.

And the real trick: never write one prompt and hope.

Generate 4 versions. Pick the best direction. Refine based on what worked. 3 rounds beats 1 "perfect" prompt every single time.

50+ tested formulas across genres.

https://frankx.ai/blog/suno-prompt-engineering-complete-guide

linkedin.content:
12,000+ AI songs later, here's the one thing I wish someone had told me on day one:

Suno doesn't follow instructions. It captures vibes.

"Make the drums louder" won't do anything. "Powerful driving drums" will completely change the track. That distinction trips up everyone, and it took me hundreds of generations to internalize.

The formula that works consistently: Genre + Tempo + Instruments + Vocals + Mood + Special Elements.

"Cinematic orchestral, 90 BPM, sweeping strings and brass, ethereal female vocals, triumphant and expansive, dramatic build" — that produces music. "Epic movie music" produces noise.

Three techniques worth remembering:

Genre stacking. Don't write "rock." Write "Alternative rock meets post-punk, angular guitars, tight rhythm section, deadpan vocals." The intersection is where Suno surprises you.

Vocal descriptors. "Whispered verses, belted chorus" gives dynamic range instantly. Describe the feeling, not the instruction.

Iterative refinement. Generate 4 versions, pick the best direction, refine. Three rounds beats one "perfect" prompt. Every time.

Complete guide with 50+ tested formulas across genres.

https://frankx.ai/blog/suno-prompt-engineering-complete-guide

#AIMusicProduction #SunoAI

"Make the drums louder" does nothing. "Powerful driving drums" changes everything.

The formula: Genre + Tempo + Instruments + Vocals + Mood + Special Elements. Plus genre stacking, vocal descriptors, and iterative refinement over single-shot prompting.

content:
Claude Code went from beta CLI to dominant AI pair programmer in 12 months. The docs are good. But the docs alone won't make you effective.

Five resources that actually move the needle:
Simon Willison. Doesn't demo tools — explains how LLMs think when they read your file system. His "LLM OS" concept is the mental model that makes everything else click.
Fireship. When Anthropic drops a feature, Fireship has a concise breakdown before you finish reading the changelog. 100 seconds of Fireship > 45 minutes of release notes.
The CLAUDE.md configuration guide. Most people skip this. One context file turns Claude from generic assistant to project-specific expert. Highest-leverage 10 minutes you'll spend.

The MCP server ecosystem. Tool integration is the difference between AI chat and AI infrastructure. Slack, Vercel, databases, image generation — all through a protocol most users haven't explored yet.

https://frankx.ai/blog/claude-code-mastery-top-resources

linkedin.content:
Claude Code went from a beta CLI to the dominant AI pair programmer in about 12 months. Multi-file refactors. Complex context windows. Tool integration through MCP.

The docs are solid. But the docs alone won't make you effective. You need to watch people who've actually pushed it to the edges.

Simon Willison explains how LLMs think when they read your file system. His "LLM OS" mental model is foundational — once you get it, everything about Claude Code makes more sense.

Fireship has the fastest breakdowns of every Anthropic feature drop. 100 seconds of Fireship saves 45 minutes of reading changelogs.

The CLAUDE.md configuration guide is the most underrated resource. One context file in your project root turns Claude from generic assistant to project-specific expert. Most people skip it. It's the highest-leverage thing you can configure.

And the MCP server ecosystem. Tool integration is what turns Claude Code from a chat interface into infrastructure. Slack, Vercel, databases, image generation — all through a protocol most users haven't explored yet.

Full curated list with learning order.

https://frankx.ai/blog/claude-code-mastery-top-resources

#ClaudeCode #DeveloperTools

newsletter.preview: Docs are good. These five things make you actually effective.
newsletter.body:
Claude Code is the dominant AI pair programmer now. The docs are solid but won't make you effective alone.

Five things that move the needle: Simon Willison for the mental model, Fireship for fast feature breakdowns, the CLAUDE.md configuration (most underrated), the MCP server ecosystem, and community patterns from production builders.

https://frankx.ai/blog/claude-code-mastery-top-resources

content:
72% of enterprise AI projects use multi-agent architectures now. Up from 23% in 2024.

That's not a trend. That's a phase change. And it happened faster than anyone predicted.

Three frameworks you need to understand:

LangGraph for stateful workflows. CrewAI for team coordination. MCP for universal tool integration.

MCP took accuracy from 49% to 88% on complex tasks. That's Claude's quiet advantage.

For solo builders: multi-agent systems let one person operate what used to require a team. I run a content pipeline where research, writing, SEO, and distribution are separate agents. All coordinated. One person's business.

For enterprises: governance is now urgent. Who approves agent decisions? How do you audit multi-agent workflows? What happens when agents disagree?

The companies figuring this out in 2026 will have a structural advantage for years.

Market context: $5.4B (2024) to $7.8B (2025). Projected $52B by 2030 at 45.8% CAGR.

Activation checklists for creators, founders, and executives.

https://frankx.ai/blog/agentic-ai-roadmap-2026

For solo builders, multi-agent means operating at team scale alone. I run a content pipeline where research, writing, SEO, and distribution are separate coordinated agents. One person. Full pipeline.

For enterprises, governance just became urgent. Who approves agent decisions? How do you audit multi-agent workflows? What happens when agents disagree? The companies figuring this out now will have a structural advantage for years.
